727160f.folder: Kissena Boulevard & Sanford Avenue, Queens, NY
727160f.text:
Kissena Boulevard, at the N.E. corner of Sanford Avenue, showing St. Joseph's Academy, a Roman Catholic home for girls.
April 8, 1927
P.L. Sperr

727161f-a.folder: Kissena Boulevard & Sanford Avenue, Queens, NY
727161f-a.text:
Kissena Boulevard, at the N.E. corner of Sanford Ave., showing in a set of three views St. Joseph's Academy now St. Joseph's Convent. St. Thomas' Hall was erected in 1838-39 and was purchased in 1860 by Catholics who opened it as a Convent School for Young Ladies under the name of St. Joseph's Academy. A new building was added and it remained the main school until the Brentwood property was acquired. St. Thomas' Hall, was a school for boys, opened on April 12, 1843. Rev. Francis L. Hawks D.D., the founder had to abandon it to his creditors. This structure for a short time also housed the Flushing Female College, but this also was no success. Additions to this building by the Academy were: Central portion erected in 1868, west wing in 1872, and the Chapel in 1879.
Sept. 4, 1897
Views 2 and 3: 1922
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

727953f-a.folder: Sanford Avenue & Kissena Boulevard, Queens, NY
727953f-a.text:
Sanford Avenue, north side, about 100 feet west of Kissena Boulevard, showing the S. Vernon mansion. In 1873 M. Hoffman, and in 1891 S.V. Mann were the owners . Jaggar Avenue a street west of the house, in 1837, was a private lane leading from Main Street to the Jaggar house. A Sunday School or Synagogue occupied the house in 1934. It is exempt for tax purposes and is registered
in the name of E. Mann in 1934.
1922
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
